questions.text: Enzymes used in gluconeogenesis are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hexokinase The gluconeogenesis enzymes which are different from glycolysis enzymes are: Pyruvate carboxylase PEPCK Fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase Glucose-6- phosphatase Enzymes of glycolysis which are also used in gluconeogenesis are: Phospho hexose isomerase Aldolase A Phospo triose isomerase Glyceraldehyde-3- phosphate dehydrogenase Phosphoglycerate kinase Phospho glycero mutase Enolase

Solution:

Denaturation, annealing, elongation Steps of PCR: Denaturation: Two DNA strands are separated by heating at ~94 °C to break hydrogen bonds. Annealing: Hybridization of primers at specific sites (one primer for each strand) at 60 °C by complementary hydrogen bonding. Extension/Elongation: Polymerization or synthesis of DNA at 72 °C by a thermostable DNA polymerase enzyme, Taq polymerase The result of one cycle of PCR is two double-stranded sequences of target DNA, each containing one newly made strand and one original strand. The cycle is repeated many times (usually 20–30) to get a billion or so copies in 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A person of 50 kg weight, his CO2 & O2 levels were measured from spirometry as CO2 = 200 ml, O2 = 250 ml. What is RQ in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

0.8 RQ of a metabolic fuel is equal to amount of CO 2 produced divided by amount of O 2 utilized for its complete oxidation. It can be given as: So, RQ for the person in question is: 200/250 = 0.8

questions.text: Highest thermic effect is of which food?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Protein Thermogenic or thermic effect of food also known as Specific dynamic action is the amount of energy required to digest, absorb, transport and metabolize that food. This is maximum for proteins followed by carbohydrates and then fats. It is different from the calorific value of a fuel. Calorific value is defined as energy obtained per gram of macromolecules undergoing complete biological oxidation. Its value varies as carbohydrates (4 kcal/gm) followed by proteins (4.2 kcal/gm) and highest for fats (9 kcal/gm).

questions.text: Methylation is needed in all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gene sequencing DNA methylation regulates alternative splicing of mRNA precursors. Exons have higher levels of DNA methylation compared to flanking introns. This allow the splicing machinery to properly identify and execution of splicing process. Process where methylation plays a role are: Gene regulation or regulation of gene expression Gene silencing/ Epigenetics Genome imprinting X-chromosome inactivation Repression of transposable elements Mismatch repair Embryonic development Maintenance of genome stability Alternate splicing DNA Replication Chromatin remodelling or heterochromatin formation Carcinogenesis Atherosclerosis, ageing B-cell differentiation Transcription Provides binding site for methyl binding proteins There is no role of methylation in DNA sequencing techniques and also in Base excision repair which mainly recognize and corrects for deaminated cytosine and adenine base pairs.

questions.text: Which represents highest free energy change in a reaction?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A As shown in the figure, the free energy change between substrates and products for all the reactions i.e. ΔG o is almost same for all the reactions because free energy change of a reaction is not dependent on the path of reaction. It is calculated simply by difference in initial energy of substrates and final energy of products. So, we have to look for second free energy change which is difference in energy of substrate and transition state ( ΔG ‡ ) or also called as free energy of activation. The order for ( ΔG ‡ ) is as ΔG A ‡ > ΔG B ‡ > ΔG C ‡ > ΔG D ‡ with highest for A and almost zero for D. So, the answer is A.

questions.text: All are true about telomerase EXCEPT –
questions.correct_answer: B. Maintains fidelity of DNA replication
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maintains fidelity of DNA replication Telomerase is the enzyme present in germ cells and stem cells of eukaryotes (Option d is true) It prevents telomere shortening in these cells and hence, maintains the length of DNA and chromosomes (Option c is true). Its activity increase in cancerous cells and decreases during ageing. So, it is responsible for the longevity of cells. This enzyme has a protein with RNA attached in its structure. This RNA act as template on which DNA is synthesized, so it is RNA dependent DNA polymerase or reverse transcriptase (Option a is true). Fidelity is related with DNA Polymerase and its proofreading ability & not with telomerase (Option b is false)

questions.text: Which B12 dependent enzyme is involved in amino acid metabolism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methionine synthase Vitamin B12 in its coenzyme form is required for following conversions: Homo cysteine to Methionine → Methionine synthase (Homocysteine N-methyl transferase). Methionine is an amino acid. Methyl Malonyl CoA - to succinyl CoA conversion → Methyl malonyl CoA Mutase. Degradation of amino acids valine, isoleucine, methionine and threonine produces propionyl CoA which get converted to methyl malonyl CoA and finally to succinyl CoA hence involve B12 dependent enzyme Methyl malonyl CoA Mutase for their metabolism. Other reaction which require B12 is conversion of UMP to dUMP (nucleotide synthesis) by Ribonucleotide Reductase.

questions.text: Cause of formation of ketone bodies or ketosis in type I Diabetes are all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Acetyl CoA not participating in TCA cycle

options.label: B
options.text: Increased activity of beta-hydroxy butyrate dehydrogenase

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decreased fatty acid oxidation In diabetes mellitus, glucose utilization is impaired due to absolute or relative insulin deficiency and due to low insulin, hormone sensitive lipase is activated causing TG mobilization from adipose tissue as fatty acids which enter liver and get broken down to form excess Acetyl CoA that serves as a precursor for ketone bodies. In type I diabetes enough, oxaloacetate is not available to combine with acetyl CoA, so acetyl CoA is diverted to ketone body synthesis. The activity of beta-hydroxy butyrate dehydrogenase an enzyme of KB synthesis which coverts acetoacetate to beta-hydroxy butyrate is also increased due to low insulin which is an inhibitor of this catabolic enzyme.

questions.text: A patient presented with pallor and cyanosis with following presentation. This condition is most probably due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B12 deficiency Knuckle pigmentation is seen in the setting of vitamin B 12 deficiency as well as in Addison’s disease. In vitamin B 12 deficiency, there is an increased production of oxidants like homocysteine. This leads to relative glutathione depletion leading to the activation of the tyrosinase enzyme. This results in the increased synthesis of melanin leading to pigmentation particularly at knuckles and oral mucosa. External markers of vitamin B 12 deficiency: Reversible knuckle pigmentation Oral mucosal pigmentation Recurrent angular stomatitis Cheilitis Polymorphic cutaneous eruption Grey, thin, dry, and lustreless hair Folic acid deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia whereas Fe deficiency results in hypochromic microcytic anemia with the hair, skin (pallor), and nail changes (koilonychia).

questions.text: While passing through PCT, which substance will increase in urine:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chloride As compared to blood the pH of urine is acidic, so generally acidic substances are thrown out in urine and basic components such as bicarbonate are reabsorbed. For amino acid and glucose there is 100% reabsorption and they will not be observed in urine. Bicarbonate being a basic component is also absorbed, but chloride is thrown out in urine, so its concentration increases in urine.

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis occurs in are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Renal tubular acidosis Metabolic acidosis is of two types: With Increased anion gap that occurs in conditions such as: Ketoacidosis (Diabetic or starvation) MSUD Biochemical organic acidemia Lactic acidosis Renal failure Uremia Toxins or poisoning of Salicylates, Methanol or Ethylene glycol With Normal anion gap that occurs in conditions such as: Renal tubular acidosis ACE inhibitors GI loss of bicarbonate

questions.text: Which enzyme has highest catalytic efficiency:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kcat =200/sec, Km = 2 micromole The best way to measure the catalytic efficiencies of different enzymes is to compare the ratio Kcat/Km for the two reactions. This parameter, is called the specificity constant, and actually is the rate constant for the conversion of E + S to E + P when [S] << Km. The greater the ratio, the higher the rate of catalysis is; conversely, the lower the ratio, the slower the catalysis is. The highest value is for option c (200/2 = 100 micromole/sec).

questions.text: Normality of 2 mM of HCl is …………. To normality of 1mM of H2SO4
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Equal Molarity (M)– moles of solute in 1L of solution. It’s a way to measure concentration of a solution. Normality (N) –It describes the equivalent moles of reactants involved in a reaction. It is always a multiple of molarity. N = M x n factor; where n factor = number of dissociable H or OH ions Normality of 2mM HCl = 2 x 1 = 2mM (for HCl, n=1; there is only 1 H ion) Normality of 1mM H 2 SO 4 = 1 x 2 = 2mM (for H 2 SO 4 , n=2; there are 2 H ion)
